Award.AwardTitle: LEAP HI: Manufacturing USA: Energy Efficient Processing of Thermoset Polymers and Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Leading Engineering for America's Prosperity, Health, and Infrastructure (LEAP-HI) project promises to dramatically reduce the cost of manufacturing high-strength composite materials. Living systems achieve form and function in ways that have little resemblance to modern manufacturing: think digits of a hand, the veins of a leaf, or the seeds of a dandelion that disperse themselves in the wind. Using nature as a model, the research will develop a new technology for the processing of plastics and composites, critical elements in structures like aircraft, automobiles and wind turbine blades, where light weight and high-strength are required. Current manufacturing of these materials is costly, to the large amounts of energy required. Drawing inspiration from living systems, this fundamental research project will result in new plastic materials that require only small initial energy input to trigger the entire manufacturing process and dramatically reduce environmental impact. This new, more efficient method has significant potential to impact and dramatically improve U.S. economic competitiveness in the critical area of composites manufacturing.

This award will enable highly collaborative, interdisciplinary research to develop a new manufacturing platform for structural polymers and composites based on an autocatalytic (self-propagating) polymerization reaction occurring in a system undergoing reaction and diffusion of its components. The system uses the exothermic release of energy to provide a positive feedback to the reaction. In turn, this stimulates further exothermic energy release, and a self-propagating reaction front that rapidly moves through the material ? a process called frontal polymerization. Once triggered, the reaction progresses with zero-energy input. The self-sustained propagation of a reaction wave through the material gives rise to entirely new ways of manufacturing high performance composites using rapid, energy efficient methods at greatly reduced costs, including 3D printing of thermosetting polymers and composites. Controlling the reaction wave by simple thermal perturbations gives rise to symmetry breaking events that can enable complex, emergent (morphogenic) pattern formation. Moreover, our biologically inspired concepts for manufacturing provide an ideal platform to inspire and educate the next generation of entrepreneurs, students, postdoctoral researchers, as well as the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Performance_Institution.Name: Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project helped start development of a new technology for the processing of plastics and composites, critical elements in structures like aircraft, automobiles and wind turbine blades, where light weight and high-strength are required. Current manufacturing of these materials is costly and energy intensive due to the large amounts of heat required. This fundamental research project examined a promising curing method known as frontal polymerization to produce thermosetting plastic materials that requires only small initial energy input to trigger the entire manufacturing process and dramatically reduce environmental impact. Our research activities for this project were divided into four collaborative areas: (1) enabling chemistries and materials, (2) manufacture and characterization, (3) processing science and modeling, and (4) broader impacts.  Significant outcomes for each area are summarized below.

(1) Over the course of the project, we explored the reactivity of 30 different monomers and characterized their performance for frontal polymerization.  Monomer properties were successfully correlated with important manufacturing parameters such as the speed of the curing process (front velocity), the pot-life of the system (gel time), and the degree of cure.  We also examined the ability of additives such phase-transitioning materials and nanoparticles to alter the curing process. 

(2) A significant reduction in cure time was achieved by the use of multiple points to thermally initiate the curing process. We developed a successful processing strategy to mitigate the thermal effects of merging fronts and produce high quality composites in less than 1 minute.  While thermal initiation is simple and effective, it provides poor spatial and temporal control over initiation and requires contact with the heat source.  We investigated the feasibility of using alternate triggers to start the curing process and demonstrated that a relatively short exposure to UV light effectively initiates the cure front.  In addition, we synthesized a force sensitive ruthenium metathesis catalyst that has significant promise for initiating frontal curing by application of mechanical force.  Finally, we studied the conditions to achieve a self-regulating cure front during 3-D printing of complex geometries.

(3) Building on the reaction-diffusion model we used to simulate frontal polymerization in neat polymers, we extended a thermo-chemical model for fiber-reinforced polymer composites.  The role of cure kinetics and external boundary conditions were investigated. We applied this model to better understand the issues of merging fronts and mitigate the resulting thermal spike.  Modeling efforts guided the design of boundary conditions (tooling surface) to eliminate the thermal spike and alleviate its negative impact on composite strength. We further modified our computational model to provide insights for maximizing the printing window.  

(4) The research team helped host a 3-day workshop led by Sandra Tsing Loh, creator of the syndicated NPR podcast, The LOH DOWN on SCIENCE. All of the graduate students on the project attended and were able to develop a 90 second elevator pitch on their research. Outreach efforts to K-12 and the general public included a successful FP demonstration as part of our Sustainable Polymers and Manufacturing exhibit at the 2019 Beckman Open House. 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/28/2020
Modified by: Nancy R Sottos

Images (1 of )
  • Composite manufacturing via frontal ring-opening metathesis polymerization (FROMP). (a) Scheme for FROMP of dicyclopentadiene (DCPD)-based liquid resin. (b) Side view and (c) top view schematics of vacuum-assisted resin transfer molding (VARTM) setup drawn to scale.
    Polette Centellas
    Nancy R Sottos
    Rapid manufacturing of composites by frontal polymerization
  • Strain map of specimen under tensile loading just before fracture (top row) and optical image of specimen after fracture (bottom row) for (a) one-front and (b) two-front tests.
    Polette Centellas, Univ. of Illinois
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Strain development under tensile loading for different processing methods
  • Thermo-chemical simulation of the merging of polymerization fronts in a carbon/DCPD composite with a 50% fiber volume fraction. In the absence of a heat sink (metallic component) placed at the merging location, a substantial thermal spike is predicted.
    Philippe Geubelle, University of Illinois
    Nancy R Sottos
    Modeling of merging fronts
  • Image of student led manufacturing demo at Beckman Open House, March 2019.
    Nancy Sottos, Univ of Illinois
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Outreach demonstration of energy efficient manufacturing.
  • Side view schematics for two heat trigger setup. The addition of a second heat trigger initiated two simultaneous fronts that merged at the panel mid-length; this region is indicated by the dotted red line and labeled as the �merged interface�.
    Polette Centellas, Univ. of Illinois
    Copyrighted
    Nancy R Sottos
    Schematic of two trigger points for faster curing
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This research project helped start development of a new technology for the processing of plastics and composites, critical elements in structures like aircraft, automobiles and wind turbine blades, where light weight and high-strength are required. Current manufacturing of these materials is costly and energy intensive due to the large amounts of heat required. This fundamental research project examined a promising curing method known as frontal polymerization to produce thermosetting plastic materials that requires only small initial energy input to trigger the entire manufacturing process and dramatically reduce environmental impact. Our research activities for this project were divided into four collaborative areas: (1) enabling chemistries and materials, (2) manufacture and characterization, (3) processing science and modeling, and (4) broader impacts. Significant outcomes for each area are summarized below. (1) Over the course of the project, we explored the reactivity of 30 different monomers and characterized their performance for frontal polymerization. Monomer properties were successfully correlated with important manufacturing parameters such as the speed of the curing process (front velocity), the pot-life of the system (gel time), and the degree of cure. We also examined the ability of additives such phase-transitioning materials and nanoparticles to alter the curing process. (2) A significant reduction in cure time was achieved by the use of multiple points to thermally initiate the curing process. We developed a successful processing strategy to mitigate the thermal effects of merging fronts and produce high quality composites in less than 1 minute. While thermal initiation is simple and effective, it provides poor spatial and temporal control over initiation and requires contact with the heat source. We investigated the feasibility of using alternate triggers to start the curing process and demonstrated that a relatively short exposure to UV light effectively initiates the cure front. In addition, we synthesized a force sensitive ruthenium metathesis catalyst that has significant promise for initiating frontal curing by application of mechanical force. Finally, we studied the conditions to achieve a self-regulating cure front during 3-D printing of complex geometries. (3) Building on the reaction-diffusion model we used to simulate frontal polymerization in neat polymers, we extended a thermo-chemical model for fiber-reinforced polymer composites. The role of cure kinetics and external boundary conditions were investigated. We applied this model to better understand the issues of merging fronts and mitigate the resulting thermal spike. Modeling efforts guided the design of boundary conditions (tooling surface) to eliminate the thermal spike and alleviate its negative impact on composite strength. We further modified our computational model to provide insights for maximizing the printing window. (4) The research team helped host a 3-day workshop led by Sandra Tsing Loh, creator of the syndicated NPR podcast, The LOH DOWN on SCIENCE. All of the graduate students on the project attended and were able to develop a 90 second elevator pitch on their research. Outreach efforts to K-12 and the general public included a successful FP demonstration as part of our Sustainable Polymers and Manufacturing exhibit at the 2019 Beckman Open House.
